title: In-Class Exercise 2: R for Geospatial Data Science
text:
Loading the following R packages:

arrow
lubridate
tidyverse
tmap
sf



Reveal Code
pacman::p_load(arrow, lubridate, tidyverse, tmap, sf)

title: In-Class Exercise 2: R for Geospatial Data Science
section: Preparing the data for use
text:
Preparing the data for use


Reveal Code
df$pingtimestamp <- as_datetime(df$pingtimestamp)

title: In-Class Exercise 2: R for Geospatial Data Science
section: Extracting the origin locations of the trips
text:
Extracting the origin locations of the trips


Reveal Code
origin_df <- df %>% 
  group_by(trj_id) %>% 
  arrange(pingtimestamp) %>% 
  filter(row_number() == 1) %>% 
  mutate(weekday = wday(pingtimestamp, label = TRUE, abbr = TRUE), start_hr = factor(hour(pingtimestamp)), day = factor(mday(pingtimestamp)))

head(origin_df)


# A tibble: 6 × 12
# Groups:   trj_id [6]
  trj_id driving_mode osname  pingtimestamp       rawlat rawlng speed bearing
  <chr>  <chr>        <chr>   <dttm>               <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>   <int>
1 70895  car          android 2019-04-08 00:09:40   1.38   104.  6.80      41
2 21926  car          android 2019-04-08 00:09:49   1.29   104. 10.8       68
3 47498  car          ios     2019-04-08 00:09:52   1.38   104. 18.3      307
4 41322  car          android 2019-04-08 00:10:00   1.28   104. 18.7      230
5 18103  car          android 2019-04-08 00:10:09   1.45   104. 14.1      155
6 64813  car          ios     2019-04-08 00:10:12   1.31   104. 19.8      109
# ℹ 4 more variables: accuracy <dbl>, weekday <ord>, start_hr <fct>, day <fct>

title: In-Class Exercise 2: R for Geospatial Data Science
section: Extracting the destination locations of the trips
text:
Extracting the destination locations of the trips


Reveal Code
destination_df <- df %>% 
  group_by(trj_id) %>% 
  arrange(desc(pingtimestamp)) %>% 
  filter(row_number() == 1) %>% 
  mutate(weekday = wday(pingtimestamp, label = TRUE, abbr = TRUE), start_hr = factor(hour(pingtimestamp)), day = factor(mday(pingtimestamp)))

head(destination_df)


# A tibble: 6 × 12
# Groups:   trj_id [6]
  trj_id driving_mode osname  pingtimestamp       rawlat rawlng speed bearing
  <chr>  <chr>        <chr>   <dttm>               <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>   <int>
1 54687  car          android 2019-04-21 23:56:37   1.44   104.  1.19     299
2 81574  car          ios     2019-04-21 23:56:33   1.34   104. 17.4      117
3 17190  car          android 2019-04-21 23:56:30   1.34   104.  9.09     201
4 13793  car          android 2019-04-21 23:56:25   1.32   104.  5.55     180
5 39014  car          ios     2019-04-21 23:56:11   1.33   104. 14.1      179
6 41170  car          ios     2019-04-21 23:56:09   1.32   104. 13.0       73
# ℹ 4 more variables: accuracy <dbl>, weekday <ord>, start_hr <fct>, day <fct>




Reveal Code
write_rds(origin_df, "Data/rds/origin_df_part0.rds")
write_rds(destination_df, "Data/rds/destination_df_part0.rds")

title: In-Class Exercise 2: R for Geospatial Data Science
section: Importing the prepared data
text: Importing the prepared data

title: In-Class Exercise 2: R for Geospatial Data Science
section: Converting the aspatial data to geospatial data
text:
Converting the aspatial data to geospatial data


Reveal Code
origin_sf <- 
  st_as_sf(origin_df, coords = c("rawlng", "rawlat"), crs = 4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs = 3414)

title: In-Class Exercise 2: R for Geospatial Data Science
section: Visualising the frequency distribution
text:
Visualising the frequency distribution


Reveal Code
ggplot(data=origin_df, 
       aes(x=weekday)) + 
  geom_bar()

title: In-Class Exercise 2: R for Geospatial Data Science
section: Visualising the trip origins as points
text:
Visualising the trip origins as points


Reveal Code
tmap_mode("plot")
tm_shape(origin_sf) +
  tm_dots()

title: In-Class Exercise 2: R for Geospatial Data Science
section: Importing the map layer
text:
Importing the map layer


Reveal Code
mpsz2019 <- st_read("Data/DataGov/MasterPlan2019SubzoneBoundaryNoSeaKML.kml") %>%
  st_transform(crs = 3414)


Reading layer `URA_MP19_SUBZONE_NO_SEA_PL' from data source 
  `C:\Users\yungq\Desktop\SMU Modules\Y4S1\Geospatial Analysis and Applications\IS415 Course Website\In-Class_Exercise\In-Class_Exercise_02\Data\DataGov\MasterPlan2019SubzoneBoundaryNoSeaKML.kml' 
  using driver `KML'
Simple feature collection with 332 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY, XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6057 ymin: 1.158699 xmax: 104.0885 ymax: 1.470775
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84

title: In-Class Exercise 2: R for Geospatial Data Science
section: Imposing the Grab trip data onto the map polygon
text:
Imposing the Grab trip data onto the map polygon


Reveal Code
tm_shape(mpsz2019) + 
  tm_polygons() + 
  tm_shape(origin_sf) +
  tm_dots()

title: Hands-On Exercise 3: 1st and 2nd Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis Methods
text:
Reveal Code
pacman::p_load(maptools, sf, raster, spatstat, tmap, readr)

title: Hands-On Exercise 3: 1st and 2nd Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis Methods
section: Deriving the coastal outline data
text:
Deriving the coastal outline data


Reveal Code
#|eval: false
#|echo: true

coastal_sf <- st_union(mpsz_sf)
plot(coastal_sf)









Reveal Code
write_rds(coastal_sf, "Data/rds/coastal-outline-2014.rds")

title: Hands-On Exercise 3: 1st and 2nd Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis Methods
section: Importing the coastal outline file
text:
Importing the coastal outline file


Reveal Code
coastal_sf <- read_rds("Data/rds/coastal-outline-2014.rds")

title: Hands-On Exercise 3: 1st and 2nd Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis Methods
section: Setting the coordinate reference system of the map layers
text:
Setting the coordinate reference system of the map layers


Reveal Code
mpsz_sf <- mpsz_sf %>%
  st_transform(crs = 3414)

coastal_sf <- coastal_sf %>% 
  st_transform(crs = 3414)

title: Hands-On Exercise 3: 1st and 2nd Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis Methods
section: Plotting the locations of pre-schools
text:
Plotting the locations of pre-schools


Reveal Code
tm_shape(mpsz_sf) + 
  tm_polygons() + 
  tm_shape(childcare_sf) +
  tm_dots()

title: Hands-On Exercise 3: 1st and 2nd Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis Methods
section: Using the “View” visualisation method
text:
Using the “View” visualisation method


Reveal Code
tmap_mode('view')

tm_shape(childcare_sf) +
  tm_dots()






Reveal Code
tmap_mode('plot')

childcare_ppp <- as(childcare_sp, "ppp")
childcare_ppp


Planar point pattern: 1925 points

plot(childcare_ppp)

summary(childcare_ppp)

section: Checking for duplicated points

title: Hands-On Exercise 3: 1st and 2nd Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis Methods
section: Handling the duplications with the jitter method
text:
Handling the duplications with the jitter method


Reveal Code
childcare_ppp_jit <- 
  rjitter(childcare_ppp, retry = TRUE, nsim = 1, drop = TRUE)

any(duplicated(childcare_ppp_jit))


[1] FALSE

title: Hands-On Exercise 3: 1st and 2nd Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis Methods
section: Conducting First-order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis
text:
Conducting First-order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis

Computing kernel density estimation using automatic bandwidth selection method


Reveal Code
kde_childcareSG_bw <- 
  density(childcareSG_ppp, sigma=bw.diggle, edge=TRUE, kernel="gaussian") 
plot(kde_childcareSG_bw)











Obtaining bandwidth used in kernel density estimation


Reveal Code
bw <- bw.diggle(childcareSG_ppp)
bw


   sigma 
295.4419 




Re-scaling the kernel density estimation


Reveal Code
childcareSG_ppp.km <- rescale(childcareSG_ppp, 1000, "km")
kde_childcareSG.bw <- 
  density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma = bw.diggle, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

plot(kde_childcareSG.bw)











Using different automatic bandwidth methods

Deriving the bandwidth of different methods


Reveal Code
bw.CvL(childcareSG_ppp.km)


  sigma 
4.54311 


Reveal Code
bw.scott(childcareSG_ppp.km)


 sigma.x  sigma.y 
2.159749 1.396455 


Reveal Code
bw.ppl(childcareSG_ppp.km)


    sigma 
0.3897017 


Reveal Code
bw.diggle(childcareSG_ppp.km)


    sigma 
0.2954419 




Comparing the ppl and diggle methods


Reveal Code
kde_childcareSG.ppl <- 
  density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

par(mfrow = c(1,2))

plot(kde_childcareSG.bw, main = "bw.diggle")
plot(kde_childcareSG.ppl, main = "bw.ppl")












Using different kernel methods


Reveal Code
par(mfrow = c(2,2))

plot(density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian"), main="Gaussian")

plot(density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "epanechnikov"), main = "Epanechnikov")

plot(density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "quartic"), main="Quartic")

plot(density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma = bw.ppl, edge = TRUE, kernel = "disc"), main="Disc")











Using a fixed bandwidth to conduct the kernel density estimation


Reveal Code
kde_childcareSG_600 <- density(childcareSG_ppp.km, sigma = 0.6, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian")

plot(kde_childcareSG_600)











Using an adaptive bandwidth to conduct the kernel density estimation


Reveal Code
kde_childcareSG_adaptive <- adaptive.density(childcareSG_ppp.km, method = "kernel")

plot(kde_childcareSG_adaptive)











Comparing the results of kernel density estimations using adaptive versus fixed bandwidths


Reveal Code
par(mfrow = c(1,2))

plot(kde_childcareSG.bw, main = "Fixed bandwidth")
plot(kde_childcareSG_adaptive, main = "Adaptive bandwidth")











Converting the kernel density estimate into a grid object


Reveal Code
gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw <- 
  as.SpatialGridDataFrame.im(kde_childcareSG.bw)

spplot(gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw)











Converting gridded output into a raster object


Reveal Code
kde_childcareSG_bw_raster <- raster(gridded_kde_childcareSG_bw)
kde_childcareSG_bw_raster


class      : RasterLayer

Reveal Code
projection(kde_childcareSG_bw_raster) <- CRS("+init=EPSG:3414")

Visualing the raster object


Reveal Code
tm_shape(kde_childcareSG_bw_raster) + 
  tm_raster("v") +
  tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"), frame = FALSE)








Comparing spatial point patterns using kernel density estimation

Extracting the polygons of interest


Reveal Code
pg = mpsz_spatial[mpsz_spatial@data$PLN_AREA_N == "PUNGGOL",]
tm = mpsz_spatial[mpsz_spatial@data$PLN_AREA_N == "TAMPINES",]
ck = mpsz_spatial[mpsz_spatial@data$PLN_AREA_N == "CHOA CHU KANG",]
jw = mpsz_spatial[mpsz_spatial@data$PLN_AREA_N == "JURONG WEST",]

par(mfrow = c(2,2))
plot(pg, main = "Ponggol")
plot(tm, main = "Tampines")
plot(ck, main = "Choa Chu Kang")
plot(jw, main = "Jurong West")











Converting the spatial polygon objects into generic “sp” objects


Reveal Code
pg_sp = as(pg, "SpatialPolygons")
tm_sp = as(tm, "SpatialPolygons")
ck_sp = as(ck, "SpatialPolygons")
jw_sp = as(jw, "SpatialPolygons")




Creating owin objects out of the polygons of interest


Reveal Code
pg_owin = as(pg_sp, "owin")
tm_owin = as(tm_sp, "owin")
ck_owin = as(ck_sp, "owin")
jw_owin = as(jw_sp, "owin")




Subset the childcare events by each area of interest


Reveal Code
childcare_pg_ppp = childcare_ppp_jit[pg_owin]
childcare_tm_ppp = childcare_ppp_jit[tm_owin]
childcare_ck_ppp = childcare_ppp_jit[ck_owin]
childcare_jw_ppp = childcare_ppp_jit[jw_owin]

childcare_pg_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_pg_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_tm_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_tm_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_ck_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_ck_ppp, 1000, "km")
childcare_jw_ppp.km = rescale(childcare_jw_ppp, 1000, "km")




Plotting the childcare events in each area of interest


Reveal Code
par(mfrow = c(2,2))
plot(childcare_pg_ppp.km, main = "Punggol")
plot(childcare_tm_ppp.km, main = "Tampines")
plot(childcare_ck_ppp.km, main = "Choa Chu Kang")
plot(childcare_jw_ppp.km, main = "Jurong West")












Conducting the kernel density estimation of each area of interest

Using automatic bandwidth (diggle algorithm)


Reveal Code
par(mfrow = c(2,2))

plot(density(childcare_pg_ppp.km, sigma = bw.diggle, edge = TRUE, kernel="gaussian"), main="Punggol")

plot(density(childcare_tm_ppp.km, sigma = bw.diggle, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian"), main = "Tempines")

plot(density(childcare_ck_ppp.km, sigma = bw.diggle, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian"), main="Choa Chu Kang")

plot(density(childcare_jw_ppp.km, sigma = bw.diggle, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian"), main = "Jurong West")











Using a fixed bandwidth


Reveal Code
par(mfrow = c(2,2))

plot(density(childcare_ck_ppp.km, sigma = 0.25, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian"), main = "Chou Chu Kang")

plot(density(childcare_jw_ppp.km, sigma = 0.25, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian"), main = "Jurong West")

plot(density(childcare_pg_ppp.km, sigma = 0.25, edge = TRUE, kernel = "gaussian"), main = "Punggol")

plot(density(childcare_tm_ppp.km, sigma = 0.25, edge = TRUE,  kernel = "gaussian"), main = "Tampines")












Nearest Neighbour analysis

Clark and Evans Test


Reveal Code
clarkevans.test(childcareSG_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = "coastal_owin", alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)



    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcareSG_ppp
R = 0.49534, p-value < 2.2e-16
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)




Clark and Evans Test: Choa Chu Kang and Tampines Planning Area


Reveal Code
clarkevans.test(childcare_ck_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = NULL, alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)



    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_ck_ppp
R = 0.86334, p-value = 0.01226
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)


Reveal Code
clarkevans.test(childcare_tm_ppp, correction = "none", clipregion = NULL, alternative = c("clustered"), nsim = 99)



    Clark-Evans test
    No edge correction
    Z-test

data:  childcare_tm_ppp
R = 0.69514, p-value = 1.409e-10
alternative hypothesis: clustered (R < 1)

title: Hands-On Exercise 3: 1st and 2nd Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis Methods
section: Conducting Second Order Spatial Point Patterns Analysis
